So, depending on the target taxa UBERon may assign a completely distinct set of tissue names to which BioSample's value does not align. To account for this problem, the tissue level has changed to uberonId - which serves two purposes. 
1- Uberon provides more precise tissue classifications than BioSample, allowing crosswalks with multiple ontologies. This provides opportunities to standardize data from distinct sources and use consistent vocabularies for downstream applications.
2 - it is in this form of id that adherence to ontology can be most easily monitored over the samples. To make all instances conform to the Ontologic's recommendation at ontologic.consumerusers.biological-database. These classifications are derived ultimately from direct interactions with knowledge bases (uberv, UniProt, PubMedCentral, or even wikiquireter). If these databases underlined BioSample records for any tissue classification information provided or updated on their own, you'd see some incongruity, because uberon ontology, when combined with the rest of the ontology tree (e.g., Eukarya), defines a distinct tissue/organ structure more specific that we're accustomed to from gene/probe databases such as BioConductor to the human/mouse to organ or local-like specific ones we see.
In general, while ontologies overlap in certain cases across databases they do not exactly align at every level of biological organization leading to the incompatibility in certain circumstances. But since you asked about tissue and organ crosswalks from uberon that's what gets returned by the API nowadays when requesting crosswalk information using the tissue attribute instead of original bioSample term alone(e.g., lung, liver from bioconductor), I have added that for crosswalks for both Gene Ontology and UniProt, this has been corrected in all sample information so far processed and is now shown.
